\usepackage[latin9]{inputenc}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}

\section*{Singularity in Likelihood}

The formula for weak lensing I used is
\begin{equation}
\epsilon=\frac{\epsilon_{0}+g}{1+g^{*}\epsilon_{0}}
\end{equation}


Here in weak lensing $|g|<1$.

To recover $\epsilon_{0}$ from $\epsilon$ use:
\begin{equation}
\epsilon_{0}=\frac{\epsilon-g}{1-g^{*}\epsilon}
\end{equation}


If we know g we know the transform rule between $\epsilon$and $\epsilon_{0}$.

Set the probability distribution of $\epsilon_{0}$ is $f(\epsilon_{0})$.Then
the probability distribution of $\epsilon$ is
\begin{equation}
p(\epsilon|g)=f(\epsilon_{0}(\epsilon,g))*|\frac{\partial(|\epsilon_{0}|,\phi_{0})}{\partial(|\epsilon|,\phi)}|
\end{equation}


The Jacobi term will cause singularity at $|\epsilon_{0}|=0$,because:
\begin{equation}
|\frac{\partial(|\epsilon_{0}|,\phi_{0})}{\partial(|\epsilon|,\phi)}|=|\frac{\partial(|\epsilon_{0}|,\phi_{0})}{\partial(x_{0},y_{0})}*\frac{\partial(x_{0},y_{0})}{\partial(x,y)}*\frac{\partial(x,y)}{\partial(|\epsilon|,\phi)}|=\frac{|\epsilon|}{|\epsilon_{0}|}*|\frac{\partial(x_{0},y_{0})}{\partial(x,y)}|
\end{equation}


When $|\epsilon_{0}|\longmapsto0$ ,$\epsilon\approx\epsilon_{0}+g$.Therefore,$|\frac{\partial(x_{0},y_{0)}}{\partial(x,y)}|\mapsto1$.

When using beta distribution model,$f(\epsilon_{0})=|\epsilon_{0}|^{\alpha-1}(1-|\epsilon_{0}|)^{\beta-1}$

Therefore,$p(\epsilon|g)=|\epsilon_{0}|^{\alpha-2}(1-|\epsilon_{0}|)^{\beta-1}*|\epsilon|*|\frac{\partial(x_{0},y_{0})}{\partial(x,y)}|$

If $\alpha<2$, $p(\epsilon|g)$ has a singular point at $\epsilon_{0}=0$.That
is,Likelihood function $L(g|\epsilon)$ has a singular point at $g=\epsilon$.
\end{document}
